newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar ends at 11-month low on stock tumble.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar ends at 11-month low on stock tumble.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar tumbled to its lowest close in nearly a year on Monday, as a big politically inspired stock-market tumble triggered strong outflows of funds to better-performing markets overseas, dealers said.
The local unit sank steadly through the day, dipping as low as T$27.775 to the U.S. dollar before ending at T$27.759 against Saturday's T$27.660 close.
It was the Taiwan dollar's lowest close since a T$27.790 finish on June 8, 1996.
Turnover through dealers was a hectic US$348.5 million.

Taiwan's stock market, beset by political jitters ahead of a planned cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday, plunged 3.72 percent or 307.55 points on Monday to close at 7,966.64 -- the index's lowest level since March 25 -- as support at 8,000 evaporated.
"The stock market plunge prompted many investors to withdraw their funds and invest them elsewhere, like in Hong Kong where the market is hot," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
"The political jitters have more direct impact on the stock market than forex, but the indirect impact is the same."
Hong Kong's share index soared to a record close on Monday.
The Taiwan dollar has been on a slow downtrend for most of 1997, with the central bank pledging a hands-off policy for the domestic foreign exchange market.

An even stronger statement of laissez-faire intent one year ago -- the central bank's decision to junk a decade-old defence of the Taiwan dollar at T$27.5 -- that sparked a significant, albeit temporary, depreciation to within a few cents of T$28.
Within weeks it had rebounded to stabilise around T$27.5.
Dealers said bank intervention this time is unlikely.
"The bank is letting the Taiwan dollar fall because the fall is purely market-driven," the foreign bank dealer said.
The central bank steadfastly defended the currency at T$27.5 in early 1996 when political and military tensions with rival China triggered a wave of capital outflow and a stock selloff.
It openly renounced intervention in May 1996 as tensions eased and has reaffirmed the hands-off policy many times since, most recently after a board meeting on Thursday.
Dealers said the central bank was allowing a depreciation in a strategy aimed at boosting exports, the island's lifeblood.
Taiwan in April posted a US$203.5 million trade deficit as exports slipped a year-on-year 2.5 percent to US$9.84 billion.
